head.title: Medicare Shouldn't Pay to Train Doctors; When Elderly Choose

hedline.hl1: Medicare Shouldn't Pay to Train Doctors; When Elderly Choose

block.p: Regarding Medicare "reform," no one seems to be addressing the drastic difference between a 65-year-old and an 85-year-old. At 65 years my father was still working as a physician and my parents were traveling and leading an active social life. Twenty years later my father is deceased and my mother resides in a nursing home, wheelchair-ridden and with severe dementia.

Regarding Medicare "reform," no one seems to be addressing the drastic difference between a 65-year-old and an 85-year-old. At 65 years my father was still working as a physician and my parents were traveling and leading an active social life. Twenty years later my father is deceased and my mother resides in a nursing home, wheelchair-ridden and with severe dementia.

My parents were elderly when the AT&T divestiture took place, and they were unable to cope with the complexities of choosing a new phone company! Until the end, they stayed with AT&T and their rented, antiquated black rotary telephone.
Does anyone in his right mind expect the "old" elderly to rejoice in being able to choose a health care plan? One would think Republicans had no parents. JUDY SMITH Stony Brook, L.I., Oct. 24, 1995
